Authors: Davies, Kirk W.; Bates, Jonathan D.; Nafus, Aleta M.
Title: Mowing Wyoming Big Sagebrush Communities With Degraded Herbaceous Understories: Has a Threshold Been Crossed?
Notes: Actually looks at shrub density and gives methedology for how they measured it (Transect). Looks also at brome in shrubland so could be a super good paper!
purpose_of_study: To determine the response of Wyoming big sagebrush plant communities with degraded herbaceous understories to mowing.

Authors: Lortie, Christopher J.; Gruber, Eva; Filazzola, Alex; Noble, Taylor; Westphal, Michael
Title: The Groot Effect: Plant facilitation and desert shrub regrowth following extensive damage
Notes: Facilitation is major component of this paper. Does not specifically look at shrub density itself but does have some mentions of density of shrubs so might be useful for this paper
purpose_of_study: To directly examine whether a common desert shrub species within California, Ephedra californica, can recover from mechanical damage introduced during a period of extended drought.

Authors: Hamilton, Bryan T.; Roeder, Beverly L.; Horner, Margaret A.
Title: Effects of Sagebrush Restoration and Conifer Encroachment on Small Mammal Diversity in Sagebrush Ecosystem
Notes: Looks at sage bush restoration and how it will facilitate a larger density of shrub and plants to be experienced. Does have some data for density
purpose_of_study: To evaluate the relationships between conifer encroachment, sagebrush restoration, and small mammal diversity in a sagebrush ecosystem over 11 yr.

Authors: FRANCOPIZANA, J; FULBRIGHT, TE; GARDINER, DT
Title: SPATIAL RELATIONS BETWEEN SHRUBS AND PROSOPIS-GLANDULOSA CANOPIES
Notes: Great paper that looks at shrub density and its association with facilitating other woody shrubs (their establishment of other woody shrubs)
purpose_of_study: To determine if ed soil nutrients and attenuation of solar radiation beneath P. glandulosa canopies facilitate establishment of subordinate shrubs and shrub cluster developmen

Authors: He, Yuhui; Liu, Xinping; Xie, Zhongkui
Title: SHRUB EFFECTS ON HERBACEOUS VEGETATION VARY WITH GROWTH STAGES AND HERB RELATIVE LOCATION
Notes: Paper looks mainly at plant density but does look at shrub density to an extent. Also looks to see if the shrubs facilitate other vegetation near them
purpose_of_study: To determine how the presence of shrubs influenced the growth of neighbouring herbaceous plants.

Authors: Noumi, Zouhaier
Title: Effects of exotic and endogenous shrubs on understory vegetation and soil nutrients in the south of Tunisia
Notes: Pretty good paper looking at various species of shrubs and density is recorded in them
purpose_of_study: To select the optimal species (exotic or endogenous) that can be used as candidate species for ecological restoration in arid zones of Tunisia.

Authors: Angelica Gomez-Ruiz, Pilar; Lindig-Cisneros, Roberto; Vargas-Rios, Orlando
Title: Facilitation among plants: A strategy for the ecological restoration of the high-andean forest (Bogota, DC-Colombia)
Notes: Does look at shrub density (medium level) and looks at facilitative interactions. Has data that can be used
purpose_of_study: To evaluate interactions between the leguminous and native species by measuring growth parameters.

Authors: Gusman-M, Elizabeth; de la Cruz, Marcelino; Espinosa, Carlos Ivan; Escudero, Adrian
Title: Focusing on individual species reveals the specific nature of assembly mechanisms in a tropical dry-forest
Notes: Has density of both trees and shrubs in  a hector area. They are included together in the same measurment. Also connects facilitative interactions with this density.
purpose_of_study: To analyze the effect of each study species on the structure of community diversity.

Authors: Mendez-Toribio, Moises; Maria Gonzalez-Di Pierro, Ana; Quesada, Mauricio; Benitez-Malvido, Julieta
Title: Regeneration beneath a dioecious tree species (Spondias purpurea) in a Mexican tropical dry forest
Notes: Paper looks at density of woody seedlings (including shrubs) and does have measurements for density (With respect to parent woody species). Also mentions facilitative effects
purpose_of_study: To determine if S. purpurea females could act as nucleation sites of initial regeneration as a result of directed dispersal and by providing highly favourable recruitment sites

Authors: Nottebrock, Henning; Esler, Karen J.; Schurr, Frank M.
Title: Effects of intraspecific and community density on the lifetime fecundity of long-lived shrubs
Notes: Looks at the density of various shrub species I africa. There are measurments and values in this pdf. I think it would be an excellent addition
purpose_of_study: A study of the density dependence of lifetime fecundity in two long-lived shrub species (Protea repens (L.) L. and Leucadendron rubrum Burm. f.) from the South African Cape Floristic Region (CFR).

Authors: Henriquez, JM; Lusk, CH
Title: Facilitation of Nothofagus antarctica (Fagaceae) seedlings by the prostrate shrub Empetrum rubrum (Empetraceae) on glacial moraines in Patagonia
Notes: Looks at shrub seedling density but not shrub density itself. Does mentiaon facilitation and such. Maybe use.
purpose_of_study: To determine the presence of an E. rubrum cover facilitate establishment of N. antarctica seedlings and what are the mechanism by which E. rubrum influence seedling establishment?

Authors: Farzam, Mohammad; Ejtehadi, Hamid
Title: Effects of drought and slope aspect on canopy facilitation in a mountainous rangeland
Notes: Looks at shrub camopy and a little bit of shrub density but not too much. Does talk about shrub seedling density though
purpose_of_study: To investigate the main effects and interactions between physiography (slope aspect), climate (normal or dry year) and canopy facilitation (presence of nurse shrubs) on the plant diversity and abundance in a semiarid mountainous rangeland.

Authors: Cipriotti, P. A.; Aguiar, M. R.
Title: Resource partitioning and interactions enable coexistence in a grass-shrub steppe
Notes: Excellent paper that follows all criteria. Has shrub and shrub density in it with facilitation as a main point of the paper. Excellent to use
purpose_of_study: To determine if different functional responses at population level occurs among shrub species according to the water partition or balanced competition mechanisms.

Authors: Li, XD; Wilson, SD
Title: Facilitation among woody plants establishing in an old field
Notes: Looks at density of shrub species as well as plant species. Also looks at transplanting the shrubs from one area to another and the facilitation of other plant growth
purpose_of_study: To examine indirect effects that could increase individual growth via suppression of neighboring grasses.

Authors: Williams, C. Jason; Pierson, Frederick B.; Kormos, Patrick R.; Al-Hamdan, Osama Z.; Nouwakpo, Sayjro K.; Weitz, Mark A.
Title: Vegetation, Hydrologic, and Erosion Responses of Sagebrush Steppe 9 Yr Following Mechanical Tree Removal
Notes: Excellent paper that has data on sagebush density and connects it to facilitation. Follows criteria needed.
purpose_of_study: To quantify the effects of tree removal by cutting and mastication on vegetation, soils, and hydrology and erosion processes at two woodlands 9 yr after treatment.

Authors: Hobbs, Trevor J.; Neumann, Craig R.; Meyer, Wayne S.; Moon, Travis; Bryan, Brett A.
Title: Models of reforestation productivity and carbon sequestration for land use and climate change adaptation planning in South Australia
Notes: Paper looks at plant density and includes all plants, shrubs and trees in these measurements. Might be a good idea to use.
purpose_of_study: To observe models that facilitate better regional land use planning decisions and counter the limitations of currently available models of reforestation productivity and carbon sequestration.

Authors: Walker, Lawrence R.; Vrooman, Steven S.; Thompson, Daniel B.
Title: Rodent mounds facilitate shrubs and shrubs inhibit seedlings in the Mojave Desert, USA
Notes: Excellent paper looking at how rodunt mounds facilitate shrubs. Looks in depth at densities of the shrubs and has data and figures to support
purpose_of_study: To examin the indirect influences of rodent activities on desert shrub diversity and density through rodent mound effects on soil resources, C. ramosissima seedling dynamics, and shrub size.

Authors: Liczner, Amanda R.; Sotomayor, Diego A.; Filazzola, Alessandro; Lortie, Christopher J.
Title: Germination response of desert annuals to shrub facilitation is species specific but not ecotypic
Notes: Ppaer looks to see if the positive interactions that are experienced between shrubs and annuals will influnce the total density of annuals. No mention of shrub density though
purpose_of_study: To we examined the hypothesis that shrubs (benefactors) influence the germination of desert annuals (beneficiaries) and promote ecotypic differentiation by generating distinct microhabitats through abiotic stress amelioration.

Authors: Dolezal, J; St'astna, P; Hara, T; Srutek, M
Title: Neighbourhood interactions and environmental factors influencing old-pasture succession in the Central Pyrenees
Notes: Paper looks more at the density of trees than the density of shrubs. Does have facilitation in the paper but not density measurement for shrubs in it
purpose_of_study: To examin the effects of  elevation, topography and surface rock cover on tree establishment and survival.

Authors: Duncan, RS; Chapman, CA
Title: Tree-shrub interactions during early secondary forest succession in Uganda
Notes: Paper looks as both shrub and tree density and how the 2 affect eachother. Has data within body of text.  Also looks to see if the densities allow for facilitation or inhibition
purpose_of_study: To determine how shrubs and other nontree vegetation (vines, grasses, herbs) affect tree recruitment and growth during the first 6 years of natural forest succession after clear felling in timber plantations in Kibale National Park, Uganda.

Authors: Madrigal-Gonzalez, Jaime; Kelt, Douglas A.; Meserve, Peter L.; Squeo, Francisco A.; Gutierrez, Julio R.
Title: Shrub-ephemeral plants interactions in semiarid north-central Chile: Is the nurse plant syndrome manifested at the community level?
Notes: Paper does look at density of species and connects with facilitative interactions
purpose_of_study: To determine if nurse-plant syndrome manifests at the community level.

Authors: Burnham, Katharine M.; Lee, Thomas D.
Title: Canopy gaps facilitate establishment, growth, and reproduction of invasive Frangula alnus in a Tsuga canadensis dominated forest
Notes: might be a good paper to include. Looks at buckthorn and density with facilitation
purpose_of_study: To determine whether buckthorn is more abundant in gaps created by logging than in uncut forests, whether buckthorn abundance in gaps is related to gap size, and whether or not buckthorn can establish and persist under a forest canopy

Authors: Casper, BB
Title: Demographic consequences of drought in the herbaceous perennial Cryptantha flava: Effects of density, associations with shrubs, and plant size
Notes: Looks more at a plant species and its relation to shrub and open areas. It mighttttt be good
purpose_of_study: To contrast mortality and plant size during drought years and non-drought years

Authors: Garcia-Cervigon, Ana I.; Gazol, Antonio; Sanz, Virginia; Julio Camarero, J.; Miguel Olano, Jose
Title: Intraspecific competition replaces interspecific facilitation as abiotic stress decreases: The shifting nature of plant-plant interactions
Notes: Ppaer does look at high density of shrubs and its affect on the facilitating seedling establishment. No measurments of density but does show that the high density of the shrub is taken into consideration
purpose_of_study: To evaluate how abiotic conditions modulate intraspecific interactions in the cushion plant_Hormathophylla spinosa_(L.) P.

Authors: Miao, Renhui; Qiu, Xueli; Guo, Meixia; Musa, Ala; Jiang, Deming
Title: Accuracy of space-for-time substitution for vegetation state prediction following shrub restoration
Notes: Shrub density is mentioned but might not be the greatest paper for shrub density and facilitation
purpose_of_study: Assess the accuracy of SFT in predicting vegetation parameter states during restoration

Authors: Porensky, Lauren M.; Leger, Elizabeth A.; Davison, Jay; Miller, W. Wally; Goergen, Erin M.; Espeland, Erin K.; Carroll-Moore, Erin M.
Title: Arid old-field restoration: Native perennial grasses suppress weeds and erosion, but also suppress native shrubs
Notes: Looks both at shrub density and its association with facilitation it seems like a good paper
purpose_of_study: To determine the separate and combined impacts of seeded perennial grasses and short-term irrigation on 5-year restoration outcomes at abandoned agricultural sites in the Great Basin

Authors: Yoshihara, Yu; Sasaki, Takehiro; Okuro, Toshiya; Undarmaa, Jamsran; Takeuchi, Kazuhiko
Title: Cross-spatial-scale patterns in the facilitative effect of shrubs and potential for restoration of desert steppe
Notes: Excellent paper and follows almost all criteria.
purpose_of_study: Whether the facilitative function of shrubs changed across spatial scales, and whether such changes had implications for enhancing sustainable use of Mongolian rangelands.

Authors: Koyama, A.; Sasaki, T.; Jamsran, U.; Okuro, T.
Title: Shrub cover regulates population dynamics of herbaceous plants at individual shrub scale on the Mongolian steppe
Notes: Annual density is mentioned as a side thing in this paper but isnt the main focus of it. So density is considered a bit. Not a lot of facilitation mentioned
purpose_of_study: To determine if shrubs regulate herbaceous plant community by modifying seed and plant distributions at the individual shrub scale.

Authors: Zuliani, M.; Ghazian, N.; Lortie, C.J.
Title: Shrub density effects on the community structure and composition of a desert animal community
Notes: Our paper.
purpose_of_study: To examin whether shrubs and increasing density of shrubs positively influence key measures of animal communities.

Authors: Spiegel, Orr; Nathan, Ran
Title: Empirical evaluation of directed dispersal and density-dependent effects across successive recruitment phases
Notes: Looks at density-dependent competition and facilitation with shrub species, both inter and intraspecific
purpose_of_study: To assess how habitat suitability and disperser effectiveness change across establishment phases by testing the DrD hypothesis across different recruitment phases.

Authors: Bueno, Andrea; Llambi, Luis D.
Title: Facilitation and edge effects influence vegetation regeneration in old-fields at the tropical Andean forest line
Notes: Looks at tree density under shrub canopies. Does not take shrub density into consideration but does have some sort of density measurements
purpose_of_study: To determine the effects of shrub canopy on different community structure.

Authors: Forbes, Adam
Title: Canopy manipulations of exotic Bitter Willow (Salix elaeagnos) forest for indigenous seedling recruitment: A pilot study
Notes: Another buckthorn paper with density included and facilitation
purpose_of_study: Small-scale (single tree) canopy manipulations would locally increase light transmission to the Bitter Willow understorey and thereby stimulate the regeneration of indigenous canopy tree seedlings.

Authors: Liu, Rentao; Liu, Jianan; Zhao, Juan; Xi, Weihua; Yang, Zhimin
Title: Ground-active arthropod recovery in response to size of shrub plantations in a desertified grassland ecosystem
Notes: Looks at various aspects of shrubs such as canopy size, canopy cover, and other aspects and how it affects the denity of athropods under them. Not density of shrubs themselves
purpose_of_study: To examine how shrub size mediated the composition and abundance distribution of ground-active arthropods and how ground-active arthropod diversity responded to shrub size

Authors: Hunter, John Thomas; Hunter, Vanessa Hewlett
Title: The complex nature of headland shrub encroachment: The case of Headland Zieria (Zieria prostrata)
Notes: Very short paper but looks at how shrub density may provide protection to understory species and increase facilitative interactions
purpose_of_study: To test the assumption that the presence of shrubs is detrimental to Headland Zieria and thus whether management actions that include fire and/or mechanical removal of shrubs are appropriate for the survival of this species or if a more nuanced approach may be necessary.

Authors: Lara-Romero, Carlos; Gusman-M, Elizabeth; Ramon, Pablo; Velez-Morac, Diego; Ivan Espinosac, Carlos
Title: Does size matter? Ontogenetic responses of an Andean shrub to conspecific density-dependence
Notes: Petty good paper that looks at shrub size, interactions and density itself. Might be fairly usefull for paper.
purpose_of_study: To study the spatial pattern of adults and recruits of the Andean shrub Croton wagneri and assessed the role of dispersal, population spatial structure and intraspecific interactions on individual plant performance.

Authors: Ballantyne, Mark; Pickering, Catherine Marina
Title: Recreational trails as a source of negative impacts on the persistence of keystone species and facilitation
Notes: Paper looks at shrub densities and even states wether the density is small and large. Connects everything with facilitation. Has data that can be used for synthesis
purpose_of_study: To assess hiking trail affects facilitation in the Windswept Feldmark.

Authors: Hughes, Nicole M.; Johnson, Daniel M.; Akhalkatsi, Maia; Abdaladze, Otar
Title: Characterizing Betula litwinowii Seeding Microsites at the Alpine-Treeline Ecotone, Central Greater Caucasus Mountains, Georgia
Notes: Paper does look at shrub density but mainly the juveniles of R. Caucasium
purpose_of_study: To evaluate the spatial association between_B. litwinowii_seedlings,_R. caucasicum_shrubs, and topographical depressions to identify possible relationships with successful seedling establishment in_B. litwinowii.

Authors: Belay, Tamrat A.; Moe, Stein R.
Title: Woody dominance in a semi-arid savanna rangeland - Evidence for competitive self-thinning
Notes: Paper does take a look at shrub density (calls it woody density), tree density and plant density. Also mentions facilitation as amain theme of the paper.
purpose_of_study: To examine whether selfthinning, as suggested by the honeycomb rippling model, is evident in a semi-arid savanna, and to assess its potential for inducing long-term stability in the woody encroached savanna patches.

Authors: Sosa, Beatriz; Brazeiro, Alejandro
Title: Positive ecosystem engineering effects of the ant Atta vollenweideri on the shrub Grabowskia duplicata
Notes: Paper looks at the density of 3 different shrub species and gives data with it and mentions facilitative effect. Can be an excellent addition
purpose_of_study: To determine the effects the ant Atta vollenweideri indirectly has on the shrub Grabowskia duplicata?

Authors: Pang, Chun-chiu; Ma, Xoni Kwan-Ki; Hung, Tony Tun-hei; Hau, Billy Chi-hang
Title: Early ecological succession on landslide trails, Hong Kong, China
Notes: Looks at restoration with regards to shrub bensity and richness in the study area. More focus on species richness and stem density than shrub population density
purpose_of_study: To investigate the species composition and abundance of plants that have established on landslide trails

Authors: Andivia, Enrique; Villar-Salvador, Pedro; Tovar, Liliana; Rabasa, Sonia; Rey Benayas, Jose M.
Title: Multiscale assessment of woody species recruitment in Mediterranean shrublands: facilitation and beyond
Notes: Looks at the density of Retama Shrubland. Measured individual shrubs in transects and found density of them.Does not specifically have density datasets but still seems like a good paper to add
purpose_of_study: To assess the relative importance of several factors in forest species recruitment in Retama sphaerocarpa (L.) Boiss (Retama) shrublands at different spatial scales.

Authors: Mendoza-Hernandez, Pedro E.; Orozco-Segovia, Alma; Meave, Jorge A.; Valverde, Teresa; Martinez-Ramos, Miguel
Title: Vegetation recovery and plant facilitation in a human-disturbed lava field in a megacity: searching tools for ecosystem restoration
Notes: Looks at density of plant species (including shrubs) and has data for it. Looks at how these densities might play a facilitative role.
purpose_of_study: To explore the potential of the dominant plant species to act as facilitators of the natural regeneration of the vegetation under the harsh environmental conditions that prevail after the disturbance.

Authors: Westphal, Michael F.; Noble, Taylor; Butterfield, Harry Scott; Lortie, Christopher J.
Title: A test of desert shrub facilitation via radiotelemetric monitoring of a diurnal lizard
Notes: Paper does talk about the density of shrubs in the study site and the facilitation
purpose_of_study: To test if shrubs facilitate lizards by providing thermoregulatory opportunities.

Authors: Christopher J. Lortie, Jenna Braun, MichaelWestphal, Taylor Noble, MarioZuliani, Emmeleia Nix, NargolGhazian, MaloryOwen & H. Scott Butterfeld
Title: Shrub and vegetation cover predict resource selection use by an endangered species of desert lizard
Notes: Resource selection paper.
purpose_of_study: To examin the probability of selection given different resource types.

Authors: Mclaren, Brian E.; Gammond, Peter R.; Thompson, Ian D.
Title: Characteristics of the boreal mixedwood forest associated with the use of subnivean access points by American martens
Notes: Directly looks at shrub density in relation with other vegetation species and the relations with them
purpose_of_study: Clusters of deciduous shrubs can provide points of access below the snow to martens additional to those provided by the CWD and low-hanging, conifer branches more typically associated with subnivean access.
